div1.p: This is a medical report on the outbreak of yellow fever in Benin, West Africa. It details the measures taken to prevent further cases.

div1.head: Translation [from French] of a medical report from 1st Class Chief Physician to the Lieutenant Governor at Dahomey, Porto-Novo, June 23, 1923
div1.opener:
? Onido (Why doh?)
TRANSLATED FROM THE FRENCH
Ferris
good last Part
Porto-Novo, June 23, 1923.
DAHOMEY COLONY
HEALTH SERVICE
The 1st Class Chief Physician,
To the Lieutenant-Governor
at Dahomey, Porto-Nov.
div1.p:
On the morning of June 6th, a telephone call from Dr. Valmorin, stationed
at Ouidah, notified the head of the Health Service that Mr. Cabanes, agent of the
F.A.O. at Ouidah, who had been sick since the first of June, had died on the night
of the 5th day of his illness, and a short time before his death had presented
the following suspicious symptoms:

“At the moment of his death, the patient vomited a certain amount of
black liquid containing dust-like substance similar to coffee grounds. A few
hours after death he turned yellow and developed hemorrhagic effusions over the
entire back of the body.”

According to the medical report which confirmed these data, Mr. A.,
on the 1st of June, came down with a severe attack of fever preceded by chills
and accompanied by bilious vomiting. The fever went up to 39.6 degrees on the
first day and persisted although gradually diminishing. Liver sensitive, cardiac
insufficiency, large quantity of albumen in the urine, constipation. On the
evening of June 5th, the patient became worse, subdelirious. The heart gave
out, the extremities became cold, and death supervened towards 3 o'clock in the
morning with the symptoms related above. At the same time two other Europeans
were sick at Ouidah, Mr. B. a French Overseas Agent, and Mr. C., an officer
in the Colonial Artillery. The first of these developed a fever with delayed
icterus, the second was reported by the doctor of the Senegalese Regiment as
having had a certain amount of fever and felt somewhat tired, but as already
improving. Learning that these two patients were getting ready to go to Cotonou,
- 2 -
the chief of the Health Service immediately forbade evacuation of all patients
coming from Ouidah (telegrams 42 and 43 of the 6th of June). At the same time
the following instructions were given to Dr. Valmorin:

In view of the grave emergency confronting us, I am asking you without
awaiting the arrival of further instructions, to take the following measures:

(1) As soon as possible install isolation accommodations for Europeans
and natives with rooms screened by a wire or strong mosquito notting.
(2) Prepare a screened stretcher for transporting patients.

(3) Undertake energetically the destruction of mosquitoes, getting in
touch with the authorities for the purpose of organizing several working squads
under guards who will take instructions from you.

(4) Evacuation of dwellings inhabited by suspects. Disinfection of these
dwellings and a sanitary cordon around the houses.
(5) Observation of persons who have had contact with suspects.

(6) Methodical house inspections among Europeans and natives for locating
the sick.

(7) Examination at the station by Assistant Physician Titus of all persons
leaving Ouidah and observation of every suspect.

You may refer to the local decree of July 5, 1906, for supplementary
sanitary measures which you may think necessary.

Without delay the local board of health was called together and at
the suggestion of the chief of the Health Service it was decided that observation
of the Ouidah settlement was necessary. A local decree of June 8th declared
Ouidah under observation.

At 8 o'clock in the morning Mr. B. died with icterus that was very
pronounced at the end, without black vomit, but with melena. These two deaths
with symptoms sufficiently characteristic, established yellow fever beyond a
- 3 -
doubt and by decree of June 9th, several hours after that of June 8th, the
city and the settlements of Ouidah were declared infected with yellow fever.

Urgent measures were necessary because it was a question not only
of combating this incipient epidemic at Ouidah, but also of avoiding at all
price the further contamination of Cotonou only 60 kilometers away and in
daily communication by rail with Ouidah. On the morning of the 9th of June
the condition of Officer C. which up till then had not been considered serious,
became worse and aroused suspicion. The head of the Health Service, who had
set out for Ouida, arrived the morning of the 10th, only to learn that this
officer had died during the night. The autopsy which he himself performed
gave him a chance to confirm the yellow fever diagnosis. Another European,
a commercial agent, was likewise attacked by the same disease, but he, Mr. D.
is at present well again. Detail orders were given on the spot by the head
of the Health Service in agreement with the Commander of the settlement, the
Military Commander, and Dr. V., the Physician of the Assistance. They consisted
of measures:

(1) To bring about, with the aid of the military authorities, the isolation
of inhabitants by means of a sanitary cordon, in order to avoid all egress of
patients to the exterior.

(2) To watch attentively any person the least bit ill, and if necessary
to place him under observation in a screened room so as to avoid surprises and
errors in diagnosis.

(3) To provide for the possible immediate dispersion to the interior of
the European population of the settlement and have in readiness isolated
dwellings.

(4) To have the military European element still in good health abandon
the portion of the city where the yellow fever had occurred and for the present
to group these Europeans in the non-contaminated Zoumai camp.
(5) To issue an order for the soldiers to retire at 6:15.
